value: Stratified random sampling means the population is divided into two or more non-overlapping groups, then members of the sample are selected at random from each group.

When the inspector selects $2$ tubs of ice cream at random of each of $5$ different flavors, he is dividing the population into two non-overlapping groups and then selecting members of the sample at random from each group. This means he is using stratified random sampling.
Simple random sampling means every member of the sample is selected at random from the entire population without any pre-planned order.

When the inspector assigns a number to each tub of ice cream in a freezer and then selects $10$ numbers at random from a hat, he is selecting every member of the sample at random without any pre-planned order. This means he is using simple random sampling.
Systematic random sampling means every member of the sample is selected at regular intervals according to a rule or pattern.

When the inspector selects every $4\text{th}$ tub of ice cream on a numerical list, he is using a pattern to select members of the sample at regular intervals. This means he is using systematic random sampling.
Systematic random sampling means every member of the sample is selected at regular intervals according to a rule or pattern.
When Alda selects every $10\text{th}$ name from an alphabetical list, she is using a pattern to select members of the sample at regular intervals. This means she is using systematic random sampling.
Stratified random sampling means the population is divided into two or more non-overlapping groups, then members of the sample are selected at random from each group.

When Alda selects $10$ names at random from alphabetical lists of $5$ different neighborhoods, she is dividing the population into non-overlapping groups and then selecting members of the sample at random from each group. This means she is using stratified random sampling.
Simple random sampling means every member of the sample is selected at random from the entire population without any pre-planned order.

When Alda writes the last name of each household on a slip of paper and then selects $40$ slips at random from a hat, she is selecting every member of the sample at random without any pre-planned order. This means she is using simple random sampling.
Stratified random sampling means the population is divided into two or more non-overlapping groups, then members of the sample are selected at random from each group.

Systematic random sampling means every member of the sample is selected at regular intervals according to a rule or pattern.

Simple random sampling means every member of the sample is selected at random from the entire population without any pre-planned order.

When Baruch writes the bib number of each runner on a slip of paper and then selects $40$ slips at random from a hat, he is selecting every member of the sample at random without any pre-planned order. This means he is using simple random sampling.
Systematic random sampling means every member of the sample is selected at regular intervals according to a rule or pattern.
